messageBody:
Thanks a lot so far. I've created MockServerSocket and now my code
is able to reliably verify that a socket connection would be accept()
ed by the ConnectionService at least. I still can't think of a way
to test that the accept()ed connection is then passed to the
ConnectionHandler (because of the slight delay after accepting). I
think you may have addressed that issue, but I'm not quite sure what
you mean by

"This could be achieved by creating a wrapper on a socket in the real
code. this wrapper simply has the responsibility to make connect()
calls to the ConnectionService whenever a real socket connection is
made."

Since you say 'in the real code', you must not be talking about a
MockServerSocket. Can you expand?

Thanks a lot. I've already improved the test tenfold.

David Weitzman

--- In junit@y..., "Matthew Cooke" <mpcooke3@h...> wrote:
> Hi.
>
> I have spent some time thinking about the problems involved with
testing
> multithreaded code. As we have had similar problems at work in the
past.
>
> The problem is that the monitor-threads model in Java is fairly
easy to
> understand to start with, but becomes difficult to apply safely in
large
> scale systems. This problem is futher compounded by the fact that
unit
> testing becomes difficult/impossible, either you test the threaded
behaviour
> and have horrible join() sleep() code or you ignore the threading
aspects.
> Even if you unit test everything the threading behaviour of a
system is
> still not captured because the 'Unit Tests' test Objects and
parellelism is
> not contained within objects in the threading model.
>
> I am sure if java used the more modern CSP (Communicating
Sequential
> Processes) model then writing junit tests would be much simpler as
each bit
> of code could be tested outside of a parrallel system. Eg, The
parallelism
> would not be hidden inside an object or spread across multiple
objects.
> Hence Unit testing and Mock CSP Objects could easily be used.
>
> Anyway - I digress.
>
> I think how I would address the problems you are having by testing
> separately the socket connection code and the behavoiur you want
the
> ConnectionService to have.
>
> This could be achieved by creating a wrapper on a socket in the
real code.
> this wrapper simply has the responsibility to make connect() calls
to the
> ConnectionService whenever a real socket connection is made.
>
> Now the tests on connectionService become non-threaded and non-
network
> related. calls made to connect should cause the mockFactory to
create an
> object. A call to stopListening should cause the mockSocketWrapper
to be
> asked to close.
>
> You could still test the 'real' behaviour of the socket itself by
testing
> the socketWrapper although I wouldn't bother. I accept that some
simple
> wrappers on java libraries don't need testing becauase hopefully
they are
> not buggy ;)
>
> Matt.
>
